title: AQL feature completion does not work on dynamic meta-models
body:
I have a dynamic metamodel (no generated Java code, just the `EPackage` created in memory), say `pkg`.
Inside of it, I have an `EClass` name `A` with an `EAttribute` `name: EString`.

I try to complete the expression `self.`, with a setup like this:

```java
IQueryCompletionEngine engine = QueryCompletion.newEngine(this.queryEnvironment);
Map<String, Set<IType>> variableTypes = new LinkedHashMap<>();
final Set<IType> potentialTypes = new LinkedHashSet<>(1);
potentialTypes.add(new EClassifierType(this.queryEnvironment, selfType));
variableTypes.put("self", potentialTypes);
return engine.getCompletion(expression, offset, variableTypes);
```
where `selfType` is my EClass `A`. The parent EPackage is correctly registered in the `queryEnvironment`.

I expect `engine.getCompletion()` to return a completion proposal for `self.name`, but it returns nothing.

After digging into the code and discussing with @ylussaud, here is what seems to happen:

1. We end up (correctly) in `BasicLookupEngine.getServices(Set<IType>)` with the correct values.
2. This code tries to find the service(s) for which `service.getParameterTypes(queryEnvironment).get(0).isAssignableFrom(type)` is `true`.
3. Inside the set of known services, we have an instance of `EObjectServices.EObjectFeatureAccess`, which is the one that should normally handle this.
4. Calling `service.getParameterTypes(queryEnvironment).get(0)` on it returns a `ClassType` representing `org.eclipse.emf.ecore.EObject`.
5. `ClassType.isAssignableFrom(IType)` only works for types which exist as Java classes, i.e. for metamodels with generated code.

At step 4, calling `service.getParameterTypes(queryEnvironment)` on `EObjectFeatureAccess` invokes the implementation of `getParameterTypes` from `JavaMethodService.getParameterTypes(IReadOnlyQueryEnvironment)`, which only returns `IJavaType`s.

Not sure if `EObjectFeatureAccess` should override `getParameterTypes` or if `JavaMethodService.getParameterTypes` itself should be updated, but if a type (here `EObject`) is actually an `EClassifier`, it should return an `EClassifierType` instead of a `ClassType`. `EClassifierType.isAssignableFrom()` uses the reflexive EMF APIs and should work correctly on dynamic metamodels.

title: NA
body: We want to make sure instances passed to `JavaMethodService` compatible a a ClassType to make sure we don't have any issue at runtime. I think it's better to add a dynamic `EObject` case in `AbstractJavaType.isAssignableFrom()`.

title: Add a way to distinguish ambiguous services.
body:
This needs comes from the following M2Doc [issue](https://github.com/ObeoNetwork/M2Doc/issues/439):
## Current behavior

When two different Java service classes each provide a service method which have the same name and parameter types, then the resolution depends on the import order.
## Expected behavior

It should be possible to disambiguate these calls, probably using aliases or fully-qualified names.
Minimal reproduction of the problem with instructions

In a Capella model, with service classes org.polarsys.capella.core.model.helpers.ProjectExt and org.polarsys.capella.common.helpers.EcoreUtil2, both org.polarsys.capella.core.model.helpers.ProjectExt.getProject(EObject) org.polarsys.capella.common.helpers.EcoreUtil2.getProject(EObject) have the same parameter types and name, so there is no way to explicitly specify which we want to use.
## What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?

We can get deadlocked if two service classes each provide two services clashing with the other, and we want to use one service from one service class, and the other service from the other class: because the resolution depends on the import order, only one of the two classes will actually be usable.

I think the current service store replace the old service by the new one. I don't think both of them are kept. That's probably the first thing to check before introducing a syntax for disambiguating service calls.

If you are familiar with Acceleo 3 there are a few changes with Acceleo 4:

* OCL has been replaced with [AQL](https://github.com/eclipse-acceleo/acceleo/blob/master/query/plugins/org.eclipse.acceleo.query.doc/input/index.textile) (for services references you can also have a look at [this page](https://eclipse.dev/acceleo/documentation/aql.html) the other page should soon includes service references).
* The indentation policy has changed to introduce mandatory indentation in the template that can be distinguished from the indentation in the generated document. Also blocks of code are inserted in a way they keep the caller indentation by repeating the last generated line if needed. You can find more details [here](https://github.com/eclipse-acceleo/acceleo/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.acceleo.aql.doc/pages/language.adoc#white-spaces). This explains the two first characters that are not in the generated output.
* The compilation to emtl has been removed.
* The main comment moved outside of the template (I though it was also the case in Acceleo 3...).

For more details about Acceleo 4, you can check the [documentation](https://github.com/eclipse-acceleo/acceleo/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.acceleo.aql.doc/toc.adoc). If you are migrating from Acceleo 3 check the [migration section](https://github.com/eclipse-acceleo/acceleo/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.acceleo.aql.doc/pages/migration.adoc) that also include more details on changes between Acceleo 3 and 4.

Also note that since the first release of Acceleo 4 we have been busy fixing a wide range of small annoying bugs and improve user experience (there is now an error marker and a quick fix when the template indentation is missing). Those fixes are not release yet but you can benefit from them by using the [last nightly build](https://download.eclipse.org/acceleo/updates/nightly/latest/). A new release 4.1.0 should be available soon, probably at the beginning of next year.

Hope that will help you get started with Acceleo 4, if you have other questions don't hesitate to ask them.

title: AcceleoUtils.getMainTemplates() should look into super modules
body:
This would allow to have a `@main` in a super module without the need to redeclare the annotation in each sub modules.
This change might change the way we launch Acceleo via the launconfig and in standalone in the case the main is in a super module.

title: When a template is called in a super module the import from that super module should be used for resolution instead of the current module.
body:
* A extends B
  * calls super:template(...)
* B import C
  * declares template(...)
    * calls otherTemplate(...)
* C
  * declares otherTemplate(...)

We should also make sure that if a template `otherTemplate(...)` with the same signature is declared in A that it is not called.

The logged message should be improved to fix the typo and also help find the source of the problem:
```
		An internal error occured during evaluation of a query
```

title: Add a command in the editor to generate template/queries for children EClasses
body: When selecting a template/query we should be able to generate templates/queries for children EClasses. For instance for a template on EClassifier it should generate the template for EClass and EDataType. We probably do this only for the first parameter.

title: Add completion to override an existing template/query.
body: When a module extends an other module we should provide the completion to override an existing template/query. This should be only available in the module outside a template/query.

title: Add an option to filter element while profiling
body:
This option could be a list of regular expression matching qualified names. When at least one of them is matched by the current qualified name profiling nodes are created in the output model.

This will allow to profile big generators and still be able to save the profiling model.

title: Add an @override tag on template and query.
body:
This should be used in validation:

* if the template/query is missing the tag and it override an other template/query
  * add a validation warning (maybe an error)
  * add a quick fix to add the missing tag, if a `@main` tag is present we probably want to add the `@override` in the same comment
* if the tag is present but the template/query doesn't override an other template/query
  * add a validation error
